message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms suggestive of Complex Regional Pain Syndrome (CRPS). The warmth, swelling, and reddish appearance of the right hand and forearm, along with the severe pain, are classic symptoms of CRPS. The normal neurological examination, normal laboratory values, and normal nerve conduction studies make cellulitis, compartment syndrome, and limb ischemia less likely.

We refer to PubMed and UpToDate articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms, including severe, deep, sharp pain, warmer, swollen, and reddish appearance of the right hand and forearm, and intense pain upon light touching, suggest complex regional pain syndrome (CRPS). Compartment syndrome is characterized by pain and swelling that worsens with movement and at rest, and can lead to nerve damage or muscle death. Limb ischemia usually presents with pain when the arm or leg is used and is relieved at rest. Cellulitis is characterized by redness, warmth, swelling, and pain in the affected area, and may be accompanied by fever and chills. None of these conditions match the patient's symptoms and medical history as closely as CRPS.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, including severe pain, warmth, swelling, and reddish appearance, suggest Complex Regional Pain Syndrome, which can be caused by trauma, such as falling on the right forearm. The normal nerve conduction studies, lack of fracture on the X-ray, and normal laboratory results rule out other options such as cellulitis, compartment syndrome, and limb ischemia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms of intense pain, warmth, swelling, and redness, which are indicative of Complex Regional Pain Syndrome (CRPS). This condition can be triggered by trauma or injury and can be worsened by diabetes. The absence of a fracture and normal nerve conduction studies rule out Compartment Syndrome and Limb Ischemia. Cellulitis would present with more generalized symptoms such as fever and malaise.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest Complex regional pain syndrome (CRPS), which is characterized by severe pain and swelling. The fact that nerve conduction studies and X-ray of the hand and forearm are normal also supports this diagnosis. Cellulitis and compartment syndrome typically present with more severe pain and there are no signs of limb ischemia in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a history of trauma and presents with severe pain, warmth, swelling, and reddish appearance of the affected limb, which are characteristic of complex regional pain syndrome (CRPS). All other options have different clinical features. Cellulitis usually presents with erythema, swelling, and warmth but not severe pain, and the laboratory results may show leukocytosis and elevated inflammatory markers. Compartment syndrome is characterized by severe pain, pallor, paresthesia, and paralysis, and the neurovascular status of the affected limb may be compromised. Limb ischemia is characterized by pain, pallor, pulselessness, paresthesia, and paralysis, and the laboratory results may show elevated creatine kinase and lactate dehydrogenase levels.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a sharp pain in her right hand and forearm, mild bruising, warmth, redness, and swelling, suggesting Complex Regional Pain Syndrome (CRPS). CPRS is also known as reflex sympathetic dystrophy (RSD). Compartment syndrome presents with numbness and paresthesia, but the neurological examination is normal in this patient. Cellulitis would present with fever, but the patient's temperature is normal. Limb ischemia would present with absent or diminished pulses, which are palpable in this patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, including the onset of pain after trauma, warm, swollen, and reddish appearance of the right hand and forearm, and intense pain upon light touching, suggest Complex Regional Pain Syndrome. The normal nerve conduction studies and lack of evidence of fracture or ischemia rule out other options like compartment syndrome and limb ischemia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s history of trauma, presence of diabetes and neuropathic pain suggest complex regional pain syndrome as the most likely diagnosis. Compartment syndrome can cause pain and swelling but would also cause paresthesias and decreased pulses. Cellulitis can look similar to complex regional pain syndrome, but would have a higher C-reactive protein level and erythrocyte sedimentation rate. Limb ischemia would have decreased pulses and pallor, which is not present in this patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms of severe pain, warmth, swelling, and reddish appearance in the right hand and forearm, along with a history of trauma, suggests complex regional pain syndrome. The laboratory test results and normal nerve conduction studies do not support other diagnoses such as cellulitis, compartment syndrome, or limb ischemia.
